sections.title: Asset Allocation Basics
sections.content: Asset allocation is the process of dividing your investments among different asset classes like stocks, bonds, and cash. This is the most important decision you'll make as an investor, as it determines about 90% of your portfolio's return and risk characteristics. Start with broad categories and then drill down to specific investments.

points.title: Determine Risk Tolerance
points.description: Use your risk assessment to decide on an appropriate stock/bond mix.

points.title: Choose Asset Classes
points.description: Select broad categories like domestic stocks, international stocks, bonds, and alternatives.

points.title: Select Investments
points.description: Choose specific funds or securities that represent each asset class.

sections.title: Keep It Simple
sections.content: Most investors do best with a simple portfolio of 3-5 low-cost index funds covering major asset classes. Complexity often leads to higher costs and poorer performance.

sections.title: Rebalancing Your Portfolio
sections.content: Rebalancing involves periodically adjusting your portfolio back to your target allocation. This ensures you maintain your desired risk level and forces you to sell high and buy low. Set up automatic rebalancing or do it annually/quarterly based on your preference.

sections.title: Build Your Portfolio
steps: Determine your target stock/bond allocation based on your risk tolerance
Select 3-5 low-cost index funds covering different asset classes
Calculate how much to invest in each fund to reach your target allocation
Set up automatic contributions and rebalancing

sections.title: Think Long-Term
sections.content: Focus on building a portfolio that you can maintain for decades. Avoid frequent changes based on short-term market movements or hot investment trends.
